content: First of all, opalfire, HE'S NOT A CHILD! He's an adult who is losing his grip, and it is frightening. He is someone who has been independent all his life, I imagine - owned/rented his own home, raised his family, earned a living, had his own car and drove himself wherever he wanted to go whenever he wanted to. Since he's living with you, I'm guessing that he has lost his wife. If they had a successful marriage of years in length, then that, too, is distressful. Instead of "disciplining" him, go with him to his next doctor's appointment and the three of you (or four if your husband goes, too) can discuss the situation. Give the man privacy and dignity. Help him when he needs it, not pampering or treating him like a child. His space should be OFF LIMITS to you, your husband, your kids - unless/until he becomes unable to maintain basic sanitation. You can cook him all the right foods, but unless HE wants to do so, he'll eat what he damn well pleases. If you were my DIL and tried this on me, I'd slap you six ways from Sunday. (I know you're trying to do the right thing, but you're going about it the wrong way. Do some homework on Google or with your local Council on Aging. There's help out there - you just have to look for it.)

content: He sounds to me like he is depressed. Does he have any friends around his age? Even though my dad buried 2 wives, he now has a girlfriend, 85. Dad goes to this Jack in the Box where he lives, nice one too. They are all vets/retirees, yak about everything in the book, lol. Maybe if you got your FIL involved with friends his age, he might start feeling better about himself. You still might need to remind him of his meds. Might want to count what is in his bottle, then that way you will know he is taking them. He needs you and your DH to help him thru this time he is going thru. Kiss him on the cheek everyonce in a while, that will make him happy too.

content: When you talk to the counselor, be sure to ask about "respite care" - that's having someone look after him while the caregivers (that's you and dh) take a well-deserved break. Diabetes can cause problems with thought processes and mood swings - especially when not well-controlled. If he's not taking his medications or eating according to directions, that may be where some of the "meanness" and personality changes are coming from. Good luck to you all; it's not an easy road.
